Though itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s somewhat surprising Thurston Moore and Beck didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t work together prior to Demolished Thoughts, their collaboration lives up to its promise, delivering an album of psychedelic chamber folk that is the perfect meeting of both artistsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ mellow sides. At times, Beck the producer feels like a junior version of his longtime collaborator Nigel Godrich -- and indeed, Beck brings some of the expansive intricacy of works like Sea Change to this set -- but here heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s truly accomplished, embellishing MooreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s songs with special effects that really are special. Ã¢â‚¬Å“IlluminineÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½'s rippling harps and sparkling electronics conjure a vast, dusky twilight filled with fireflies, while the strings and layers of other sounds on Ã¢â‚¬Å“Blood Never LiesÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ float along like pieces of dandelion fluff. These filigrees add a beauty that doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get in the way of MooreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s strumming and melodies, whether theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re angular or flowing, or both, as is the case with Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mina LoyÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½'s descending drones. Beck also adds a trippy depth to Demolished Thoughts that is often breathtaking, particularly on Ã¢â‚¬Å“Circulation,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ a tone poem about vinyl that grows from atonal acoustic riffing into a sound-world of sawing, strafing strings, and on Ã¢â‚¬Å“In the Silver Rain with a Paper KeyÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½'s meditative shimmer. This approach is a big change from MooreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s previous solo effort, the much more down-to-earth Trees Outside the Academy, which felt like a more distinct entity from Moore's work with Sonic Youth. In some ways, Demolished Thoughts' size and polish rivals anything heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s done with them, and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hard not to hear echoes of the band on several of these songs. Ã¢â‚¬Å“BenedictionÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ opens the album with the kind of pastoral ruminations Moore has been dabbling in since Washing Machine, albeit given an extra glow thanks to the hypnotic layers of percussion, keyboards, and strings woven throughout. Meanwhile, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Orchard StreetÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½'s stream-of-consciousness evocation of New York feels like itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just down the block from Murray St. Of course, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hardly bad or surprising that MooreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s work resembles itself, especially not when the results are this compelling.
